line: shall fall in love with Beatrice. If we can do this,

scene: SCENE I.  A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Cupid is no longer an archer: his glory shall be

scene: SCENE I.  A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: ours, for we are the only love-gods. Go in with me,

scene: SCENE I.  A hall in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: and I will tell you my drift.

speaker: DON JOHN
line: It is so; the Count Claudio shall marry the

speaker: DON JOHN
line: daughter of Leonato.

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Yea, my lord; but I can cross it.

speaker: DON JOHN
line: Any bar, any cross, any impediment will be

speaker: DON JOHN
line: medicinable to me: I am sick in displeasure to him,

speaker: DON JOHN
line: and whatsoever comes athwart his affection ranges

speaker: DON JOHN
line: evenly with mine. How canst thou cross this marriage?

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Not honestly, my lord; but so covertly that no

speaker: BORACHIO
line: dishonesty shall appear in me.

speaker: DON JOHN
line: Show me briefly how.

speaker: BORACHIO
line: I think I told your lordship a year since, how much

speaker: BORACHIO
line: I am in the favour of Margaret, the waiting

speaker: BORACHIO
line: gentlewoman to Hero.

speaker: DON JOHN
line: I remember.

speaker: BORACHIO
line: I can, at any unseasonable instant of the night,

speaker: BORACHIO
line: appoint her to look out at her lady's chamber window.

speaker: DON JOHN
line: What life is in that, to be the death of this marriage?

speaker: BORACHIO
line: The poison of that lies in you to temper. Go you to

speaker: BORACHIO
line: the prince your brother; spare not to tell him that

speaker: BORACHIO
line: he hath wronged his honour in marrying the renowned

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Claudio--whose estimation do you mightily hold

speaker: BORACHIO
line: up--to a contaminated stale, such a one as Hero.

speaker: DON JOHN
line: What proof shall I make of that?

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Proof enough to misuse the prince, to vex Claudio,

speaker: BORACHIO
line: to undo Hero and kill Leonato. Look you for any

speaker: BORACHIO
line: other issue?

speaker: DON JOHN
line: Only to despite them, I will endeavour any thing.

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Go, then; find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and

speaker: BORACHIO
line: the Count Claudio alone: tell them that you know

speaker: BORACHIO
line: that Hero loves me; intend a kind of zeal both to the

speaker: BORACHIO
line: prince and Claudio, as,--in love of your brother's

speaker: BORACHIO
line: honour, who hath made this match, and his friend's

speaker: BORACHIO
line: reputation, who is thus like to be cozened with the

speaker: BORACHIO
line: semblance of a maid,--that you have discovered

speaker: BORACHIO
line: thus. They will scarcely believe this without trial:

speaker: BORACHIO
line: offer them instances; which shall bear no less

speaker: BORACHIO
line: likelihood than to see me at her chamber-window,

speaker: BORACHIO
line: hear me call Margaret Hero, hear Margaret term me

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Claudio; and bring them to see this the very night

speaker: BORACHIO
line: before the intended wedding,--for in the meantime I

speaker: BORACHIO
line: will so fashion the matter that Hero shall be

speaker: BORACHIO
line: absent,--and there shall appear such seeming truth

speaker: BORACHIO
line: of Hero's disloyalty that jealousy shall be called

speaker: BORACHIO
line: assurance and all the preparation overthrown.

speaker: DON JOHN
line: Grow this to what adverse issue it can, I will put

speaker: DON JOHN
line: it in practise. Be cunning in the working this, and

speaker: DON JOHN
line: thy fee is a thousand ducats.

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Be you constant in the accusation, and my cunning

speaker: BORACHIO
line: shall not shame me.

speaker: DON JOHN
line: I will presently go learn their day of marriage.

speaker: BENEDICK
line: Boy!

speaker: Boy
line: Signior?

speaker: BENEDICK
line: In my chamber-window lies a book: bring it hither

speaker: BENEDICK
line: to me in the orchard.

speaker: Boy
line: I am here already, sir.

speaker: BENEDICK
line: I know that; but I would have thee hence, and here again.

speaker: BENEDICK
line: I do much wonder that one man, seeing how much

speaker: BENEDICK
line: another man is a fool when he dedicates his

speaker: BENEDICK
line: behaviors to love, will, after he hath laughed at

speaker: BENEDICK
line: such shallow follies in others, become the argument

speaker: BENEDICK
line: of his own scorn by failing in love: and such a man

speaker: BENEDICK
line: is Claudio. I have known when there was no music

speaker: BENEDICK
line: with him but the drum and the fife; and now had he

speaker: BENEDICK
line: rather hear the tabour and the pipe: I have known

speaker: BENEDICK
line: when he would have walked ten mile a-foot to see a

speaker: BENEDICK
line: good armour; and now will he lie ten nights awake,

speaker: BENEDICK
line: carving the fashion of a new doublet. He was wont to

speaker: BENEDICK
line: speak plain and to the purpose, like an honest man

speaker: BENEDICK
line: and a soldier; and now is he turned orthography; his

speaker: BENEDICK
line: words are a very fantastical banquet, just so many

speaker: BENEDICK
line: strange dishes. May I be so converted and see with

speaker: BENEDICK
line: these eyes? I cannot tell; I think not: I will not

speaker: BENEDICK
line: be sworn, but love may transform me to an oyster; but

speaker: BENEDICK
line: I'll take my oath on it, till he have made an oyster

speaker: BENEDICK
line: of me, he shall never make me such a fool. One woman

speaker: BENEDICK
line: is fair, yet I am well; another is wise, yet I am

speaker: BENEDICK
line: well; another virtuous, yet I am well; but till all

speaker: BENEDICK
line: graces be in one woman, one woman shall not come in

speaker: BENEDICK
line: my grace. Rich she shall be, that's certain; wise,

speaker: BENEDICK
line: or I'll none; virtuous, or I'll never cheapen her;

speaker: BENEDICK
line: fair, or I'll   never look on her; mild, or come not

speaker: BENEDICK
line: near me; noble, or not I for an angel; of good

speaker: BENEDICK
line: discourse, an excellent musician, and her hair shall

speaker: BENEDICK
line: be of what colour it please God. Ha! the prince and

speaker: BENEDICK
line: Monsieur Love! I will hide me in the arbour.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Come, shall we hear this music?

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Yea, my good lord. How still the evening is,

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: As hush'd on purpose to grace harmony!

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: See you where Benedick hath hid himself?

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: O, very well, my lord: the music ended,

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: We'll fit the kid-fox with a pennyworth.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Come, Balthasar, we'll hear that song again.

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: O, good my lord, tax not so bad a voice

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: To slander music any more than once.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: It is the witness still of excellency

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: To put a strange face on his own perfection.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: I pray thee, sing, and let me woo no more.

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: Because you talk of wooing, I will sing;

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: Since many a wooer doth commence his suit

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: To her he thinks not worthy, yet he wooes,

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: Yet will he swear he loves.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Now, pray thee, come;

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Or, if thou wilt hold longer argument,

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Do it in notes.

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: Note this before my notes;

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: There's not a note of mine that's worth the noting.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Why, these are very crotchets that he speaks;

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Note, notes, forsooth, and nothing.

speaker: BENEDICK
line: Now, divine air! now is his soul ravished! Is it

speaker: BENEDICK
line: not strange that sheeps' guts should hale souls out

speaker: BENEDICK
line: of men's bodies? Well, a horn for my money, when

speaker: BENEDICK
line: all's done.

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more,

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: Men were deceivers ever,

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: One foot in sea and one on shore,

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: To one thing constant never:

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: Then sigh not so, but let them go,

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: And be you blithe and bonny,

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: Converting all your sounds of woe

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: Into Hey nonny, nonny.

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: Sing no more ditties, sing no moe,

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: Of dumps so dull and heavy;

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: The fraud of men was ever so,

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: Since summer first was leafy:

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: Then sigh not so, &c.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: By my troth, a good song.

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: And an ill singer, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Ha, no, no, faith; thou singest well enough for a shift.

speaker: BENEDICK
line: An he had been a dog that should have howled thus,

speaker: BENEDICK
line: they would have hanged him: and I pray God his bad

speaker: BENEDICK
line: voice bode no mischief. I had as lief have heard the

speaker: BENEDICK
line: night-raven, come what plague could have come after

speaker: BENEDICK
line: it.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Yea, marry, dost thou hear, Balthasar? I pray thee,

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: get us some excellent music; for to-morrow night we

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: would have it at the Lady Hero's chamber-window.

speaker: BALTHASAR
line: The best I can, my lord.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Do so: farewell.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Come hither, Leonato. What was it you told me of

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: to-day, that your niece Beatrice was in love with

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Signior Benedick?

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: O, ay: stalk on. stalk on; the fowl sits. I did

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: never think that lady would have loved any man.

speaker: LEONATO
line: No, nor I neither; but most wonderful that she

speaker: LEONATO
line: should so dote on Signior Benedick, whom she hath in

speaker: LEONATO
line: all outward behaviors seemed ever to abhor.

speaker: BENEDICK
line: Is't possible? Sits the wind in that corner?

speaker: LEONATO
line: By my troth, my lord, I cannot tell what to think

speaker: LEONATO
line: of it but that she loves him with an enraged

speaker: LEONATO
line: affection: it is past the infinite of thought.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: May be she doth but counterfeit.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Faith, like enough.

speaker: LEONATO
line: O God, counterfeit! There was never counterfeit of

speaker: LEONATO
line: passion came so near the life of passion as she

speaker: LEONATO
line: discovers it.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Why, what effects of passion shows she?

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Bait the hook well; this fish will bite.

speaker: LEONATO
line: What effects, my lord? She will sit you, you heard

speaker: LEONATO
line: my daughter tell you how.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: She did, indeed.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: How, how, pray you? You amaze me: I would have I

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: thought her spirit had been invincible against all

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: assaults of affection.

speaker: LEONATO
line: I would have sworn it had, my lord; especially

speaker: LEONATO
line: against Benedick.

speaker: BENEDICK
line: I should think this a gull, but that the

speaker: BENEDICK
line: white-bearded fellow speaks it: knavery cannot,

speaker: BENEDICK
line: sure, hide himself in such reverence.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: He hath ta'en the infection: hold it up.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Hath she made her affection known to Benedick?

speaker: LEONATO
line: No; and swears she never will: that's her torment.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: 'Tis true, indeed; so your daughter says: 'Shall

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: I,' says she, 'that have so oft encountered him

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: with scorn, write to him that I love him?'

speaker: LEONATO
line: This says she now when she is beginning to write to

speaker: LEONATO
line: him; for she'll be up twenty times a night, and

speaker: LEONATO
line: there will she sit in her smock till she have writ a

speaker: LEONATO
line: sheet of paper: my daughter tells us all.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Now you talk of a sheet of paper, I remember a

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: pretty jest your daughter told us of.

speaker: LEONATO
line: O, when she had writ it and was reading it over, she

speaker: LEONATO
line: found Benedick and Beatrice between the sheet?

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: That.

speaker: LEONATO
line: O, she tore the letter into a thousand halfpence;

speaker: LEONATO
line: railed at herself, that she should be so immodest

speaker: LEONATO
line: to write to one that she knew would flout her; 'I

speaker: LEONATO
line: measure him,' says she, 'by my own spirit; for I

speaker: LEONATO
line: should flout him, if he writ to me; yea, though I

speaker: LEONATO
line: love him, I should.'

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps, sobs,

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: beats her heart, tears her hair, prays, curses; 'O

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: sweet Benedick! God give me patience!'

speaker: LEONATO
line: She doth indeed; my daughter says so: and the

speaker: LEONATO
line: ecstasy hath so much overborne her that my daughter

speaker: LEONATO
line: is sometime afeared she will do a desperate outrage

speaker: LEONATO
line: to herself: it is very true.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: It were good that Benedick knew of it by some

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: other, if she will not discover it.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: To what end? He would make but a sport of it and

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: torment the poor lady worse.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: An he should, it were an alms to hang him. She's an

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: excellent sweet lady; and, out of all suspicion,

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: she is virtuous.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: And she is exceeding wise.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: In every thing but in loving Benedick.

speaker: LEONATO
line: O, my lord, wisdom and blood combating in so tender

speaker: LEONATO
line: a body, we have ten proofs to one that blood hath

speaker: LEONATO
line: the victory. I am sorry for her, as I have just

speaker: LEONATO
line: cause, being her uncle and her guardian.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: I would she had bestowed this dotage on me: I would

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: have daffed all other respects and made her half

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: myself. I pray you, tell Benedick of it, and hear

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: what a' will say.

speaker: LEONATO
line: Were it good, think you?

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Hero thinks surely she will die; for she says she

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: will die, if he love her not, and she will die, ere

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: she make her love known, and she will die, if he woo

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: her, rather than she will bate one breath of her

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: accustomed crossness.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: She doth well: if she should make tender of her

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: love, 'tis very possible he'll scorn it; for the

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: man, as you know all, hath a contemptible spirit.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: He is a very proper man.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: He hath indeed a good outward happiness.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Before God! and, in my mind, very wise.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: He doth indeed show some sparks that are like wit.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: And I take him to be valiant.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: As Hector, I assure you: and in the managing of

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: quarrels you may say he is wise; for either he

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: avoids them with great discretion, or undertakes

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: them with a most Christian-like fear.

speaker: LEONATO
line: If he do fear God, a' must necessarily keep peace:

speaker: LEONATO
line: if he break the peace, he ought to enter into a

speaker: LEONATO
line: quarrel with fear and trembling.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: And so will he do; for the man doth fear God,

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: howsoever it seems not in him by some large jests

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: he will make. Well I am sorry for your niece. Shall

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: we go seek Benedick, and tell him of her love?

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Never tell him, my lord: let her wear it out with

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: good counsel.

speaker: LEONATO
line: Nay, that's impossible: she may wear her heart out first.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Well, we will hear further of it by your daughter:

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: let it cool the while. I love Benedick well; and I

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: could wish he would modestly examine himself, to see

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: how much he is unworthy so good a lady.

speaker: LEONATO
line: My lord, will you walk? dinner is ready.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: If he do not dote on her upon this, I will never

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: trust my expectation.

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Let there be the same net spread for her; and that

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: must your daughter and her gentlewomen carry. The

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: sport will be, when they hold one an opinion of

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: another's dotage, and no such matter: that's the

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: scene that I would see, which will be merely a

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: dumb-show. Let us send her to call him in to dinner.

speaker: BENEDICK
line: Coming forward  This can be no trick: the

speaker: BENEDICK
line: conference was sadly borne. They have the truth of

speaker: BENEDICK
line: this from Hero. They seem to pity the lady: it

speaker: BENEDICK
line: seems her affections have their full bent. Love me!

speaker: BENEDICK
line: why, it must be requited. I hear how I am censured:

speaker: BENEDICK
line: they say I will bear myself proudly, if I perceive

speaker: BENEDICK
line: the love come from her; they say too that she will

speaker: BENEDICK
line: rather die than give any sign of affection. I did

speaker: BENEDICK
line: never think to marry: I must not seem proud: happy

speaker: BENEDICK
line: are they that hear their detractions and can put

speaker: BENEDICK
line: them to mending. They say the lady is fair; 'tis a

speaker: BENEDICK
line: truth, I can bear them witness; and virtuous; 'tis

speaker: BENEDICK
line: so, I cannot reprove it; and wise, but for loving

speaker: BENEDICK
line: me; by my troth, it is no addition to her wit, nor

speaker: BENEDICK
line: no great argument of her folly, for I will be

speaker: BENEDICK
line: horribly in love with her. I may chance have some

speaker: BENEDICK
line: odd quirks and remnants of wit broken on me,

speaker: BENEDICK
line: because I have railed so long against marriage: but

speaker: BENEDICK
line: doth not the appetite alter? a man loves the meat

speaker: BENEDICK
line: in his youth that he cannot endure in his age.

speaker: BENEDICK
line: Shall quips and sentences and these paper bullets of

speaker: BENEDICK
line: the brain awe a man from the career of his humour?

speaker: BENEDICK
line: No, the world must be peopled. When I said I would

speaker: BENEDICK
line: die a bachelor, I did not think I should live till I

speaker: BENEDICK
line: were married. Here comes Beatrice. By this day!

speaker: BENEDICK
line: she's a fair lady: I do spy some marks of love in

speaker: BENEDICK
line: her.

speaker: BEATRICE
line: Against my will I am sent to bid you come in to dinner.

speaker: BENEDICK
line: Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.

speaker: BEATRICE
line: I took no more pains for those thanks than you take

speaker: BEATRICE
line: pains to thank me: if it had been painful, I would

speaker: BEATRICE
line: not have come.

speaker: BENEDICK
line: You take pleasure then in the message?

speaker: BEATRICE
line: Yea, just so much as you may take upon a knife's

speaker: BEATRICE
line: point and choke a daw withal. You have no stomach,

speaker: BEATRICE
line: signior: fare you well.

speaker: BENEDICK
line: Ha! 'Against my will I am sent to bid you come in

speaker: BENEDICK
line: to dinner;' there's a double meaning in that 'I took

speaker: BENEDICK
line: no more pains for those thanks than you took pains

speaker: BENEDICK
line: to thank me.' that's as much as to say, Any pains

speaker: BENEDICK
line: that I take for you is as easy as thanks. If I do

speaker: BENEDICK
line: not take pity of her, I am a villain; if I do not

speaker: BENEDICK
line: love her, I am a Jew. I will go get her picture.

speaker: HERO
line: Good Margaret, run thee to the parlor;

speaker: HERO
line: There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice

speaker: HERO
line: Proposing with the prince and Claudio:

speaker: HERO
line: Whisper her ear and tell her, I and Ursula

speaker: HERO
line: Walk in the orchard and our whole discourse

speaker: HERO
line: Is all of her; say that thou overheard'st us;

speaker: HERO
line: And bid her steal into the pleached bower,

speaker: HERO
line: Where honeysuckles, ripen'd by the sun,

speaker: HERO
line: Forbid the sun to enter, like favourites,

speaker: HERO
line: Made proud by princes, that advance their pride

speaker: HERO
line: Against that power that bred it: there will she hide her,

speaker: HERO
line: To listen our purpose.  This is thy office;

speaker: HERO
line: Bear thee well in it and leave us alone.

speaker: MARGARET
line: I'll make her come, I warrant you, presently.

speaker: HERO
line: Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come,

speaker: HERO
line: As we do trace this alley up and down,

speaker: HERO
line: Our talk must only be of Benedick.

speaker: HERO
line: When I do name him, let it be thy part

speaker: HERO
line: To praise him more than ever man did merit:

speaker: HERO
line: My talk to thee must be how Benedick

speaker: HERO
line: Is sick in love with Beatrice. Of this matter

speaker: HERO
line: Is little Cupid's crafty arrow made,

speaker: HERO
line: That only wounds by hearsay.

speaker: HERO
line: Now begin;

speaker: HERO
line: For look where Beatrice, like a lapwing, runs

speaker: HERO
line: Close by the ground, to hear our conference.

speaker: URSULA
line: The pleasant'st angling is to see the fish

speaker: URSULA
line: Cut with her golden oars the silver stream,

speaker: URSULA
line: And greedily devour the treacherous bait:

speaker: URSULA
line: So angle we for Beatrice; who even now

speaker: URSULA
line: Is couched in the woodbine coverture.

speaker: URSULA
line: Fear you not my part of the dialogue.

speaker: HERO
line: Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing

speaker: HERO
line: Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it.

speaker: HERO
line: No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful;

speaker: HERO
line: I know her spirits are as coy and wild

speaker: HERO
line: As haggerds of the rock.

speaker: URSULA
line: But are you sure

speaker: URSULA
line: That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?

speaker: HERO
line: So says the prince and my new-trothed lord.

speaker: URSULA
line: And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?

speaker: HERO
line: They did entreat me to acquaint her of it;

speaker: HERO
line: But I persuaded them, if they loved Benedick,

speaker: HERO
line: To wish him wrestle with affection,

speaker: HERO
line: And never to let Beatrice know of it.

speaker: URSULA
line: Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman

speaker: URSULA
line: Deserve as full as fortunate a bed

speaker: URSULA
line: As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?

speaker: HERO
line: O god of love! I know he doth deserve

speaker: HERO
line: As much as may be yielded to a man:

speaker: HERO
line: But Nature never framed a woman's heart

speaker: HERO
line: Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice;

speaker: HERO
line: Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes,

speaker: HERO
line: Misprising what they look on, and her wit

speaker: HERO
line: Values itself so highly that to her

speaker: HERO
line: All matter else seems weak: she cannot love,

speaker: HERO
line: Nor take no shape nor project of affection,

speaker: HERO
line: She is so self-endeared.

speaker: URSULA
line: Sure, I think so;

speaker: URSULA
line: And therefore certainly it were not good

speaker: URSULA
line: She knew his love, lest she make sport at it.

speaker: HERO
line: Why, you speak truth. I never yet saw man,

speaker: HERO
line: How wise, how noble, young, how rarely featured,

speaker: HERO
line: But she would spell him backward: if fair-faced,

speaker: HERO
line: She would swear the gentleman should be her sister;

speaker: HERO
line: If black, why, Nature, drawing of an antique,

speaker: HERO
line: Made a foul blot; if tall, a lance ill-headed;

speaker: HERO
line: If low, an agate very vilely cut;

speaker: HERO
line: If speaking, why, a vane blown with all winds;

speaker: HERO
line: If silent, why, a block moved with none.

speaker: HERO
line: So turns she every man the wrong side out

speaker: HERO
line: And never gives to truth and virtue that

speaker: HERO
line: Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.

speaker: URSULA
line: Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.

speaker: HERO
line: No, not to be so odd and from all fashions

speaker: HERO
line: As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable:

speaker: HERO
line: But who dare tell her so? If I should speak,

speaker: HERO
line: She would mock me into air; O, she would laugh me

speaker: HERO
line: Out of myself, press me to death with wit.

speaker: HERO
line: Therefore let Benedick, like cover'd fire,

speaker: HERO
line: Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly:

speaker: HERO
line: It were a better death than die with mocks,

speaker: HERO
line: Which is as bad as die with tickling.

speaker: URSULA
line: Yet tell her of it: hear what she will say.

speaker: HERO
line: No; rather I will go to Benedick

speaker: HERO
line: And counsel him to fight against his passion.

speaker: HERO
line: And, truly, I'll devise some honest slanders

speaker: HERO
line: To stain my cousin with: one doth not know

speaker: HERO
line: How much an ill word may empoison liking.

speaker: URSULA
line: O, do not do your cousin such a wrong.

speaker: URSULA
line: She cannot be so much without true judgment--

speaker: URSULA
line: Having so swift and excellent a wit

speaker: URSULA
line: As she is prized to have--as to refuse

speaker: URSULA
line: So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.

speaker: HERO
line: He is the only man of Italy.

speaker: HERO
line: Always excepted my dear Claudio.

speaker: URSULA
line: I pray you, be not angry with me, madam,

speaker: URSULA
line: Speaking my fancy: Signior Benedick,

speaker: URSULA
line: For shape, for bearing, argument and valour,

speaker: URSULA
line: Goes foremost in report through Italy.

speaker: HERO
line: Indeed, he hath an excellent good name.

speaker: URSULA
line: His excellence did earn it, ere he had it.

speaker: URSULA
line: When are you married, madam?

speaker: HERO
line: Why, every day, to-morrow. Come, go in:

speaker: HERO
line: I'll show thee some attires, and have thy counsel

speaker: HERO
line: Which is the best to furnish me to-morrow.

speaker: URSULA
line: She's limed, I warrant you: we have caught her, madam.

speaker: HERO
line: If it proves so, then loving goes by haps:

speaker: HERO
line: Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps.

speaker: BEATRICE
line: Coming forward

speaker: BEATRICE
line: What fire is in mine ears? Can this be true?

speaker: BEATRICE
line: Stand I condemn'd for pride and scorn so much?

speaker: BEATRICE
line: Contempt, farewell! and maiden pride, adieu!

speaker: BEATRICE
line: No glory lives behind the back of such.

speaker: BEATRICE
line: And, Benedick, love on; I will requite thee,

speaker: BEATRICE
line: Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand:

speaker: BEATRICE
line: If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee

speaker: BEATRICE
line: To bind our loves up in a holy band;

speaker: BEATRICE
line: For others say thou dost deserve, and I

speaker: BEATRICE
line: Believe it better than reportingly.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: then go I toward Arragon.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: I'll bring you thither, my lord, if you'll

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: vouchsafe me.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: of your marriage as to show a child his new coat

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: and forbid him to wear it. I will only be bold

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: with Benedick for his company; for, from the crown

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: of his head to the sole of his foot, he is all

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: mirth: he hath twice or thrice cut Cupid's

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: bow-string and the little hangman dare not shoot at

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: him; he hath a heart as sound as a bell and his

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinks his

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: tongue speaks.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: BENEDICK
line: Gallants, I am not as I have been.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: LEONATO
line: So say I methinks you are sadder.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: I hope he be in love.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Hang him, truant! there's no true drop of blood in

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: him, to be truly touched with love: if he be sad,

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: he wants money.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: BENEDICK
line: I have the toothache.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Draw it.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: BENEDICK
line: Hang it!

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: What! sigh for the toothache?

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: LEONATO
line: Where is but a humour or a worm.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: BENEDICK
line: Well, every one can master a grief but he that has

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: BENEDICK
line: it.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Yet say I, he is in love.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless it be

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: a fancy that he hath to strange disguises; as, to be

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: a Dutchman today, a Frenchman to-morrow, or in the

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: shape of two countries at once, as, a German from

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: the waist downward, all slops, and a Spaniard from

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: the hip upward, no doublet. Unless he have a fancy

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: to this foolery, as it appears he hath, he is no

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: If he be not in love with some woman, there is no

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: believing old signs: a' brushes his hat o'

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: mornings; what should that bode?

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Hath any man seen him at the barber's?

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: No, but the barber's man hath been seen with him,

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: and the old ornament of his cheek hath already

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: stuffed tennis-balls.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: LEONATO
line: Indeed, he looks younger than he did, by the loss of a beard.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Nay, a' rubs himself with civet: can you smell him

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: out by that?

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: That's as much as to say, the sweet youth's in love.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: The greatest note of it is his melancholy.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: And when was he wont to wash his face?

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Yea, or to paint himself? for the which, I hear

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: what they say of him.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Nay, but his jesting spirit; which is now crept into

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: a lute-string and now governed by stops.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Indeed, that tells a heavy tale for him: conclude,

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: conclude he is in love.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Nay, but I know who loves him.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: That would I know too: I warrant, one that knows him not.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Yes, and his ill conditions; and, in despite of

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: all, dies for him.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: She shall be buried with her face upwards.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: BENEDICK
line: Yet is this no charm for the toothache. Old

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: BENEDICK
line: signior, walk aside with me: I have studied eight

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: BENEDICK
line: or nine wise words to speak to you, which these

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: BENEDICK
line: hobby-horses must not hear.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: For my life, to break with him about Beatrice.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: 'Tis even so. Hero and Margaret have by this

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: played their parts with Beatrice; and then the two

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: bears will not bite one another when they meet.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: My lord and brother, God save you!

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Good den, brother.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: If your leisure served, I would speak with you.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: In private?

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: If it please you: yet Count Claudio may hear; for

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: what I would speak of concerns him.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: What's the matter?

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: To CLAUDIO  Means your lordship to be married

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: to-morrow?

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: You know he does.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: I know not that, when he knows what I know.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: You may think I love you not: let that appear

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: hereafter, and aim better at me by that I now will

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: manifest. For my brother, I think he holds you

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: well, and in dearness of heart hath holp to effect

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: your ensuing marriage;--surely suit ill spent and

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: labour ill bestowed.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Why, what's the matter?

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: I came hither to tell you; and, circumstances

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: shortened, for she has been too long a talking of,

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: the lady is disloyal.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Who, Hero?

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Even she; Leonato's Hero, your Hero, every man's Hero:

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Disloyal?

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: The word is too good to paint out her wickedness; I

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: could say she were worse: think you of a worse

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: title, and I will fit her to it. Wonder not till

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: further warrant: go but with me to-night, you shall

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: see her chamber-window entered, even the night

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: before her wedding-day: if you love her then,

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: to-morrow wed her; but it would better fit your honour

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: to change your mind.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: May this be so?

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: I will not think it.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: If you dare not trust that you see, confess not

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: that you know: if you will follow me, I will show

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: you enough; and when you have seen more and heard

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: more, proceed accordingly.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: If I see any thing to-night why I should not marry

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: her to-morrow in the congregation, where I should

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: wed, there will I shame her.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: And, as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will join

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: with thee to disgrace her.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: I will disparage her no farther till you are my

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: witnesses: bear it coldly but till midnight, and

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: let the issue show itself.

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON PEDRO
line: O day untowardly turned!

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: CLAUDIO
line: O mischief strangely thwarting!

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: O plague right well prevented! so will you say when

scene: SCENE II.  A room in LEONATO'S house
speaker: DON JOHN
line: you have seen the sequel.

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Are you good men and true?

speaker: VERGES
line: Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer

speaker: VERGES
line: salvation, body and soul.

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Nay, that were a punishment too good for them, if

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: they should have any allegiance in them, being

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: chosen for the prince's watch.

speaker: VERGES
line: Well, give them their charge, neighbour Dogberry.

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: First, who think you the most desertless man to be

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: constable?

speaker: First Watchman
line: Hugh Otecake, sir, or George Seacole; for they can

speaker: First Watchman
line: write and read.

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Come hither, neighbour Seacole. God hath blessed

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: you with a good name: to be a well-favoured man is

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: the gift of fortune; but to write and read comes by nature.

speaker: Second Watchman
line: Both which, master constable,--

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: You have: I knew it would be your answer. Well,

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: for your favour, sir, why, give God thanks, and make

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: no boast of it; and for your writing and reading,

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: let that appear when there is no need of such

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: vanity. You are thought here to be the most

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: senseless and fit man for the constable of the

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: watch; therefore bear you the lantern. This is your

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: charge: you shall comprehend all vagrom men; you are

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: to bid any man stand, in the prince's name.

speaker: Second Watchman
line: How if a' will not stand?

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Why, then, take no note of him, but let him go; and

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: presently call the rest of the watch together and

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: thank God you are rid of a knave.

speaker: VERGES
line: If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none

speaker: VERGES
line: of the prince's subjects.

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: True, and they are to meddle with none but the

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: prince's subjects. You shall also make no noise in

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: the streets; for, for the watch to babble and to

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: talk is most tolerable and not to be endured.

speaker: Watchman
line: We will rather sleep than talk: we know what

speaker: Watchman
line: belongs to a watch.

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: watchman; for I cannot see how sleeping should

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: offend: only, have a care that your bills be not

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: stolen. Well, you are to call at all the

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: ale-houses, and bid those that are drunk get them to bed.

speaker: Watchman
line: How if they will not?

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Why, then, let them alone till they are sober: if

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: they make you not then the better answer, you may

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: say they are not the men you took them for.

speaker: Watchman
line: Well, sir.

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: If you meet a thief, you may suspect him, by virtue

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: of your office, to be no true man; and, for such

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: kind of men, the less you meddle or make with them,

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: why the more is for your honesty.

speaker: Watchman
line: If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay

speaker: Watchman
line: hands on him?

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Truly, by your office, you may; but I think they

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: that touch pitch will be defiled: the most peaceable

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: way for you, if you do take a thief, is to let him

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: show himself what he is and steal out of your company.

speaker: VERGES
line: You have been always called a merciful man, partner.

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Truly, I would not hang a dog by my will, much more

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: a man who hath any honesty in him.

speaker: VERGES
line: If you hear a child cry in the night, you must call

speaker: VERGES
line: to the nurse and bid her still it.

speaker: Watchman
line: How if the nurse be asleep and will not hear us?

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Why, then, depart in peace, and let the child wake

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: her with crying; for the ewe that will not hear her

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: lamb when it baes will never answer a calf when he bleats.

speaker: VERGES
line: 'Tis very true.

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: This is the end of the charge:--you, constable, are

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: to present the prince's own person: if you meet the

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: prince in the night, you may stay him.

speaker: VERGES
line: Nay, by'r our lady, that I think a' cannot.

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Five shillings to one on't, with any man that knows

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: the statutes, he may stay him: marry, not without

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: the prince be willing; for, indeed, the watch ought

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: to offend no man; and it is an offence to stay a

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: man against his will.

speaker: VERGES
line: By'r lady, I think it be so.

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Ha, ha, ha! Well, masters, good night: an there be

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: any matter of weight chances, call up me: keep your

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: fellows' counsels and your own; and good night.

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Come, neighbour.

speaker: Watchman
line: Well, masters, we hear our charge: let us go sit here

speaker: Watchman
line: upon the church-bench till two, and then all to bed.

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: One word more, honest neighbours. I pray you watch

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: about Signior Leonato's door; for the wedding being

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: there to-morrow, there is a great coil to-night.

speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Adieu: be vigitant, I beseech you.

speaker: BORACHIO
line: What Conrade!

speaker: Watchman
line: Aside  Peace! stir not.

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Conrade, I say!

speaker: CONRADE
line: Here, man; I am at thy elbow.

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Mass, and my elbow itched; I thought there would a

speaker: BORACHIO
line: scab follow.

speaker: CONRADE
line: I will owe thee an answer for that: and now forward

speaker: CONRADE
line: with thy tale.

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Stand thee close, then, under this pent-house, for

speaker: BORACHIO
line: it drizzles rain; and I will, like a true drunkard,

speaker: BORACHIO
line: utter all to thee.

speaker: Watchman
line: Aside  Some treason, masters: yet stand close.

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Therefore know I have earned of Don John a thousand ducats.

speaker: CONRADE
line: Is it possible that any villany should be so dear?

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Thou shouldst rather ask if it were possible any

speaker: BORACHIO
line: villany should be so rich; for when rich villains

speaker: BORACHIO
line: have need of poor ones, poor ones may make what

speaker: BORACHIO
line: price they will.

speaker: CONRADE
line: I wonder at it.

speaker: BORACHIO
line: That shows thou art unconfirmed. Thou knowest that

speaker: BORACHIO
line: the fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is

speaker: BORACHIO
line: nothing to a man.

speaker: CONRADE
line: Yes, it is apparel.

speaker: BORACHIO
line: I mean, the fashion.

speaker: CONRADE
line: Yes, the fashion is the fashion.

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Tush! I may as well say the fool's the fool. But

speaker: BORACHIO
line: seest thou not what a deformed thief this fashion

speaker: BORACHIO
line: is?

speaker: Watchman
line: Aside  I know that Deformed; a' has been a vile

speaker: Watchman
line: thief this seven year; a' goes up and down like a

speaker: Watchman
line: gentleman: I remember his name.

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Didst thou not hear somebody?

speaker: CONRADE
line: No; 'twas the vane on the house.

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Seest thou not, I say, what a deformed thief this

speaker: BORACHIO
line: fashion is? how giddily a' turns about all the hot

speaker: BORACHIO
line: bloods between fourteen and five-and-thirty?

speaker: BORACHIO
line: sometimes fashioning them like Pharaoh's soldiers

speaker: BORACHIO
line: in the reeky painting, sometime like god Bel's

speaker: BORACHIO
line: priests in the old church-window, sometime like the

speaker: BORACHIO
line: shaven Hercules in the smirched worm-eaten tapestry,

speaker: BORACHIO
line: where his codpiece seems as massy as his club?

speaker: CONRADE
line: All this I see; and I see that the fashion wears

speaker: CONRADE
line: out more apparel than the man. But art not thou

speaker: CONRADE
line: thyself giddy with the fashion too, that thou hast

speaker: CONRADE
line: shifted out of thy tale into telling me of the fashion?

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Not so, neither: but know that I have to-night

speaker: BORACHIO
line: wooed Margaret, the Lady Hero's gentlewoman, by the

speaker: BORACHIO
line: name of Hero: she leans me out at her mistress'

speaker: BORACHIO
line: chamber-window, bids me a thousand times good

speaker: BORACHIO
line: night,--I tell this tale vilely:--I should first

speaker: BORACHIO
line: tell thee how the prince, Claudio and my master,

speaker: BORACHIO
line: planted and placed and possessed by my master Don

speaker: BORACHIO
line: John, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable encounter.

speaker: CONRADE
line: And thought they Margaret was Hero?

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Two of them did, the prince and Claudio; but the

speaker: BORACHIO
line: devil my master knew she was Margaret; and partly

speaker: BORACHIO
line: by his oaths, which first possessed them, partly by

speaker: BORACHIO
line: the dark night, which did deceive them, but chiefly

speaker: BORACHIO
line: by my villany, which did confirm any slander that

speaker: BORACHIO
line: Don John had made, away went Claudio enraged; swore

speaker: BORACHIO
line: he would meet her, as he was appointed, next morning

speaker: BORACHIO
line: at the temple, and there, before the whole

speaker: BORACHIO
line: congregation, shame her with what he saw o'er night

speaker: BORACHIO
line: and send her home again without a husband.

speaker: First Watchman
line: We charge you, in the prince's name, stand!

speaker: Second Watchman
line: Call up the right master constable. We have here

speaker: Second Watchman
line: recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that

speaker: Second Watchman
line: ever was known in the commonwealth.

speaker: First Watchman
line: And one Deformed is one of them: I know him; a'

speaker: First Watchman
line: wears a lock.

speaker: CONRADE
line: Masters, masters,--

speaker: Second Watchman
line: You'll be made bring Deformed forth, I warrant you.

speaker: CONRADE
line: Masters,--

speaker: First Watchman
line: Never speak: we charge you let us obey you to go with us.

speaker: BORACHIO
line: We are like to prove a goodly commodity, being taken

speaker: BORACHIO
line: up of these men's bills.

speaker: CONRADE
line: A commodity in question, I warrant you. Come, we'll obey you.

speaker: HERO
line: Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice, and desire

speaker: HERO
line: her to rise.

speaker: URSULA
line: I will, lady.

speaker: HERO
line: And bid her come hither.

speaker: URSULA
line: Well.

speaker: MARGARET
line: Troth, I think your other rabato were better.

speaker: HERO
line: No, pray thee, good Meg, I'll wear this.

speaker: MARGARET
line: By my troth, 's not so good; and I warrant your

speaker: MARGARET
line: cousin will say so.

speaker: HERO
line: My cousin's a fool, and thou art another: I'll wear

speaker: HERO
line: none but this.

speaker: MARGARET
line: I like the new tire within excellently, if the hair

speaker: MARGARET
line: were a thought browner; and your gown's a most rare

speaker: MARGARET
line: fashion, i' faith. I saw the Duchess of Milan's

speaker: MARGARET
line: gown that they praise so.

speaker: HERO
line: O, that exceeds, they say.

speaker: MARGARET
line: By my troth, 's but a night-gown in respect of

speaker: MARGARET
line: yours: cloth o' gold, and cuts, and laced with

speaker: MARGARET
line: silver, set with pearls, down sleeves, side sleeves,

speaker: MARGARET
line: and skirts, round underborne with a bluish tinsel:

speaker: MARGARET
line: but for a fine, quaint, graceful and excellent

speaker: MARGARET
line: fashion, yours is worth ten on 't.

speaker: HERO
line: God give me joy to wear it! for my heart is

speaker: HERO
line: exceeding heavy.

speaker: MARGARET
line: 'Twill be heavier soon by the weight of a man.

speaker: HERO
line: Fie upon thee! art not ashamed?

speaker: MARGARET
line: Of what, lady? of speaking honourably? Is not

speaker: MARGARET
line: marriage honourable in a beggar? Is not your lord

speaker: MARGARET
line: honourable without marriage? I think you would have

speaker: MARGARET
line: me say, 'saving your reverence, a husband:' and bad

speaker: MARGARET
line: thinking do not wrest true speaking, I'll offend

speaker: MARGARET
line: nobody: is there any harm in 'the heavier for a

speaker: MARGARET
line: husband'? None, I think, and it be the right husband

speaker: MARGARET
line: and the right wife; otherwise 'tis light, and not

speaker: MARGARET
line: heavy: ask my Lady Beatrice else; here she comes.

speaker: HERO
line: Good morrow, coz.

speaker: BEATRICE
line: Good morrow, sweet Hero.

speaker: HERO
line: Why how now? do you speak in the sick tune?

speaker: BEATRICE
line: I am out of all other tune, methinks.

speaker: MARGARET
line: Clap's into 'Light o' love;' that goes without a

speaker: MARGARET
line: burden: do you sing it, and I'll dance it.

speaker: BEATRICE
line: Ye light o' love, with your heels! then, if your

speaker: BEATRICE
line: husband have stables enough, you'll see he shall

speaker: BEATRICE
line: lack no barns.

speaker: MARGARET
line: O illegitimate construction! I scorn that with my heels.

speaker: BEATRICE
line: 'Tis almost five o'clock, cousin; tis time you were

speaker: BEATRICE
line: ready. By my troth, I am exceeding ill: heigh-ho!

speaker: MARGARET
line: For a hawk, a horse, or a husband?

speaker: BEATRICE
line: For the letter that begins them all, H.

speaker: MARGARET
line: Well, and you be not turned Turk, there's no more

speaker: MARGARET
line: sailing by the star.

speaker: BEATRICE
line: What means the fool, trow?

speaker: MARGARET
line: Nothing I; but God send every one their heart's desire!

speaker: HERO
line: These gloves the count sent me; they are an

speaker: HERO
line: excellent perfume.

speaker: BEATRICE
line: I am stuffed, cousin; I cannot smell.

speaker: MARGARET
line: A maid, and stuffed! there's goodly catching of cold.

speaker: BEATRICE
line: O, God help me! God help me! how long have you

speaker: BEATRICE
line: professed apprehension?

speaker: MARGARET
line: Even since you left it. Doth not my wit become me rarely?

speaker: BEATRICE
line: It is not seen enough, you should wear it in your

speaker: BEATRICE
line: cap. By my troth, I am sick.

speaker: MARGARET
line: Get you some of this distilled Carduus Benedictus,

speaker: MARGARET
line: and lay it to your heart: it is the only thing for a qualm.

speaker: HERO
line: There thou prickest her with a thistle.

speaker: BEATRICE
line: Benedictus! why Benedictus? you have some moral in

speaker: BEATRICE
line: this Benedictus.

speaker: MARGARET
line: Moral! no, by my troth, I have no moral meaning; I

speaker: MARGARET
line: meant, plain holy-thistle. You may think perchance

speaker: MARGARET
line: that I think you are in love: nay, by'r lady, I am

speaker: MARGARET
line: not such a fool to think what I list, nor I list

speaker: MARGARET
line: not to think what I can, nor indeed I cannot think,

speaker: MARGARET
line: if I would think my heart out of thinking, that you

speaker: MARGARET
line: are in love or that you will be in love or that you

speaker: MARGARET
line: can be in love. Yet Benedick was such another, and

speaker: MARGARET
line: now is he become a man: he swore he would never

speaker: MARGARET
line: marry, and yet now, in despite of his heart, he eats

speaker: MARGARET
line: his meat without grudging: and how you may be

speaker: MARGARET
line: converted I know not, but methinks you look with

speaker: MARGARET
line: your eyes as other women do.

speaker: BEATRICE
line: What pace is this that thy tongue keeps?

speaker: MARGARET
line: Not a false gallop.

speaker: URSULA
line: Madam, withdraw: the prince, the count, Signior

speaker: URSULA
line: Benedick, Don John, and all the gallants of the

speaker: URSULA
line: town, are come to fetch you to church.

speaker: HERO
line: Help to dress me, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: LEONATO
line: What would you with me, honest neighbour?

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Marry, sir, I would have some confidence with you

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: that decerns you nearly.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: LEONATO
line: Brief, I pray you; for you see it is a busy time with me.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Marry, this it is, sir.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: VERGES
line: Yes, in truth it is, sir.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: LEONATO
line: What is it, my good friends?

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little off the

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: matter: an old man, sir, and his wits are not so

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: blunt as, God help, I would desire they were; but,

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: in faith, honest as the skin between his brows.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: VERGES
line: Yes, I thank God I am as honest as any man living

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: VERGES
line: that is an old man and no honester than I.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Comparisons are odorous: palabras, neighbour Verges.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: LEONATO
line: Neighbours, you are tedious.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: It pleases your worship to say so, but we are the

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: poor duke's officers; but truly, for mine own part,

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: if I were as tedious as a king, I could find it in

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: my heart to bestow it all of your worship.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: LEONATO
line: All thy tediousness on me, ah?

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Yea, an 'twere a thousand pound more than 'tis; for

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: I hear as good exclamation on your worship as of any

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: man in the city; and though I be but a poor man, I

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: am glad to hear it.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: VERGES
line: And so am I.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: LEONATO
line: I would fain know what you have to say.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: VERGES
line: Marry, sir, our watch to-night, excepting your

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: VERGES
line: worship's presence, ha' ta'en a couple of as arrant

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: VERGES
line: knaves as any in Messina.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: A good old man, sir; he will be talking: as they

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: say, when the age is in, the wit is out: God help

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: us! it is a world to see. Well said, i' faith,

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: neighbour Verges: well, God's a good man; an two men

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: ride of a horse, one must ride behind. An honest

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: soul, i' faith, sir; by my troth he is, as ever

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: broke bread; but God is to be worshipped; all men

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: are not alike; alas, good neighbour!

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: LEONATO
line: Indeed, neighbour, he comes too short of you.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Gifts that God gives.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: LEONATO
line: I must leave you.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: One word, sir: our watch, sir, have indeed

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: comprehended two aspicious persons, and we would

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: have them this morning examined before your worship.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: LEONATO
line: Take their examination yourself and bring it me: I

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: LEONATO
line: am now in great haste, as it may appear unto you.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: It shall be suffigance.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: LEONATO
line: Drink some wine ere you go: fare you well.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: Messenger
line: My lord, they stay for you to give your daughter to

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: Messenger
line: her husband.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: LEONATO
line: I'll wait upon them: I am ready.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: Go, good partner, go, get you to Francis Seacole;

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: bid him bring his pen and inkhorn to the gaol: we

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: are now to examination these men.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: VERGES
line: And we must do it wisely.

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: We will spare for no wit, I warrant you; here's

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: that shall drive some of them to a non-come: only

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: get the learned writer to set down our

scene: SCENE V.  Another room in LEONATO'S house.
speaker: DOGBERRY
line: excommunication and meet me at the gaol.

speaker: LEONATO
line: Come, Friar Francis, be brief; only to the plain

speaker: LEONATO
line: form of marriage, and you shall recount their

speaker: LEONATO
line: particular duties afterwards.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
line: You come hither, my lord, to marry this lady.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: No.

speaker: LEONATO
line: To be married to her: friar, you come to marry her.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
line: Lady, you come hither to be married to this count.

speaker: HERO
line: I do.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
line: If either of you know any inward impediment why you

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
line: should not be conjoined, charge you, on your souls,

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
line: to utter it.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Know you any, Hero?

speaker: HERO
line: None, my lord.

speaker: FRIAR FRANCIS
line: Know you any, count?

speaker: LEONATO
line: I dare make his answer, none.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: O, what men dare do! what men may do! what men daily

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: do, not knowing what they do!

speaker: BENEDICK
line: How now! interjections? Why, then, some be of

speaker: BENEDICK
line: laughing, as, ah, ha, he!

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Stand thee by, friar. Father, by your leave:

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Will you with free and unconstrained soul

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Give me this maid, your daughter?

speaker: LEONATO
line: As freely, son, as God did give her me.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: And what have I to give you back, whose worth

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: May counterpoise this rich and precious gift?

speaker: DON PEDRO
line: Nothing, unless you render her again.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Sweet prince, you learn me noble thankfulness.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: There, Leonato, take her back again:

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Give not this rotten orange to your friend;

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: She's but the sign and semblance of her honour.

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Behold how like a maid she blushes here!

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: O, what authority and show of truth

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Can cunning sin cover itself withal!

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Comes not that blood as modest evidence

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: To witness simple virtue? Would you not swear,

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: All you that see her, that she were a maid,

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: By these exterior shows? But she is none:

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: She knows the heat of a luxurious bed;

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Her blush is guiltiness, not modesty.

speaker: LEONATO
line: What do you mean, my lord?

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Not to be married,

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Not to knit my soul to an approved wanton.

speaker: LEONATO
line: Dear my lord, if you, in your own proof,

speaker: LEONATO
line: Have vanquish'd the resistance of her youth,

speaker: LEONATO
line: And made defeat of her virginity,--

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: I know what you would say: if I have known her,

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: You will say she did embrace me as a husband,

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: And so extenuate the 'forehand sin:

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: No, Leonato,

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: I never tempted her with word too large;

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: But, as a brother to his sister, show'd

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Bashful sincerity and comely love.

speaker: HERO
line: And seem'd I ever otherwise to you?

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Out on thee! Seeming! I will write against it:

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: You seem to me as Dian in her orb,

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: As chaste as is the bud ere it be blown;

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: But you are more intemperate in your blood

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: Than Venus, or those pamper'd animals

speaker: CLAUDIO
line: That rage in savage sensuality.

speaker: HERO
line: Is my lord well, that he doth speak so wide?

speaker: LEONATO

line: woman: and so, I pray thee, call Beatrice: I give
